articles.headline: Bernanke’s Bid for a Second Term at the Fed Hits Resistance
articles.snippet: Even if Ben S. Bernanke’s nomination is approved, the anxiety surrounding it shows how both parties are trying to understand anger toward the government and Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Even if Ben S. Bernanke’s nomination is approved, the anxiety surrounding it shows how both parties are trying to understand anger toward the government and Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration struggled on Friday to secure confirmation of Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, underscoring the political upheaval as both parties tried to find their footing amid a powerful wave of populism.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Free Checking Could Go the Way of Free Toasters
articles.snippet: Overdraft fees had helped to subsidize free checking, but as those fees begin to fall, free checking may disappear.
articles.abstract: Overdraft fees had helped to subsidize free checking, but as those fees begin to fall, free checking may disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Free checking began as a privilege. Once it spread, customers felt entitled. Eventually, it became a commodity, as most banks felt they needed to offer it. Soon, people took it for granted.

articles.headline: Supplier Accused of Bribes for U.N. Contracts
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors have accused Richard T. Bistrong of paying business bribes to get contracts to supply protective gear to United Nations peacekeeping forces.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors have accused Richard T. Bistrong of paying business bribes to get contracts to supply protective gear to United Nations peacekeeping forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, according to people briefed on the case, a Florida businessman went undercover to play the part of a corrupt sales executive in a foreign bribery sting that led to nearly two dozen arrests and 16 indictments announced earlier this week.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Deaths Prompt Surge in U.S. Drone Strikes
articles.snippet: Since a suicide bombing that killed seven Americans in Afghanistan, the Central Intelligence Agency has employed an intensive series of strikes against militants in Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Since a suicide bombing that killed seven Americans in Afghanistan, the Central Intelligence Agency has employed an intensive series of strikes against militants in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Since the suicide bombing that took the lives of seven Americans in Afghanistan on Dec. 30, the Central Intelligence Agency has struck back against militants in Pakistan with the most intensive series of missile strikes from drone aircraft since the covert program began.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Defending Their Dealerships
articles.snippet: Hundreds of General Motors and Chrysler dealers are fighting to get back their businesses through an arbitration process that will begin next week.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of General Motors and Chrysler dealers are fighting to get back their businesses through an arbitration process that will begin next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Calisi says he believes he lost his Chrysler-Jeep dealership on Long Island because he irritated a company executive.

articles.headline: Most U.S. Union Members Are Working for the Government, New Data Shows
articles.snippet: With the loss of jobs in automaking and construction, the private sector lost union members, while government increased its organized members.
articles.abstract: With the loss of jobs in automaking and construction, the private sector lost union members, while government increased its organized members.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in American history, a majority of union members are government workers rather than private-sector employees, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced on Friday.

articles.headline: Republicans Strain to Ride Tea Party Tiger
articles.snippet: Republicans are trying to harness the Tea Party energy that helped an unknown to a Massachusetts Senate seat.
articles.abstract: Republicans are trying to harness the Tea Party energy that helped an unknown to a Massachusetts Senate seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they look to make gains in statehouses and Congress this year, Republicans are trying to harness the Tea Party energy that helped make an unknown named Scott Brown the senator-elect from Massachusetts.

articles.headline: 24 States’ Laws Open to Attack After Campaign Finance Ruling
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court decision does not overturn all relevant state laws, experts said, but the laws will face court challenges or will be repealed by legislatures.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court decision does not overturn all relevant state laws, experts said, but the laws will face court challenges or will be repealed by legislatures.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Wisconsin, conservative and pro-business groups said Friday that they were considering a lawsuit to block a proposed law that would ban corporate spending during political campaigns.

articles.headline: A Rift at the Fed Over the Bailout of A.I.G.
articles.snippet: Documents submitted to investigators examining the rescue of A.I.G. show that officials at the Federal Reserve were divided over the bailout and its long-term implications.
articles.abstract: Documents submitted to investigators examining the rescue of A.I.G. show that officials at the Federal Reserve were divided over the bailout and its long-term implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: New documents submitted to Congressional investigators examining the 2008 rescue of the American International Group show that officials at the Federal Reserve were deeply divided over the structure of the bailout and its long-term implications.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Banks May Get Help to Escape Risk Limits
articles.snippet: Policy makers are considering allowing bank holding companies to drop that status to avoid proposed limits on banks with federally insured deposits.
articles.abstract: Policy makers are considering allowing bank holding companies to drop that status to avoid proposed limits on banks with federally insured deposits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a year after the government stepped in to aid Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley by granting them access to the federal safety net, policy makers are developing an exit path that would allow them and others to escape limits on banks being proposed by the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Foot on Bomb, Marine Defies a Taliban Trap
articles.snippet: A near-miss with an I.E.D. began a journey through the Taliban’s tactics and led to an affirmation of friendship.
articles.abstract: A near-miss with an I.E.D. began a journey through the Taliban’s tactics and led to an affirmation of friendship.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOSHARAK, Afghanistan  If luck is the battlefield’s final arbiter  the wild card that can trump fitness, training, teamwork, equipment, character and skill  then Lance Cpl. Ryan T. Mathison experienced its purest and most welcome form.

articles.headline: Obama Moves to Centralize Control Over Party Strategy
articles.snippet: President Obama is reconstituting the team that helped him win the White House to counter Republican challenges in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: President Obama is reconstituting the team that helped him win the White House to counter Republican challenges in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is reconstituting the team that helped him win the White House to counter Republican challenges in the midterm elections and recalibrate after political setbacks that have narrowed his legislative ambitions.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Peter Baker

articles.headline: For Richer or for ... Not Quite as Rich
articles.snippet: Every era needs an emblematic tycoon, and for the age of the Great Recession, you couldn’t do better than Peter M. Brant, a media billionaire facing a very public divorce.
articles.abstract: Every era needs an emblematic tycoon, and for the age of the Great Recession, you couldn’t do better than Peter M. Brant, a media billionaire facing a very public divorce.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY era needs an emblematic tycoon, and for the age of the Great Recession, you couldn’t do better than Peter M. Brant.

articles.headline: Why Is a Utility Paying Customers?
articles.snippet: As saving energy becomes a rallying cry, Idaho Power is in the vanguard, paying farmers and others to cut peak use.
articles.abstract: As saving energy becomes a rallying cry, Idaho Power is in the vanguard, paying farmers and others to cut peak use.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho

articles.headline: Resetting the Moral Compass
articles.snippet: President Obama’s plan wouldn’t prevent every bad bet on Wall Street, but it would remind banks of whose money they are gambling.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s plan wouldn’t prevent every bad bet on Wall Street, but it would remind banks of whose money they are gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was great to see President Obama renew his focus on financial reform last week, even if it looked like an attempt to distract voters from his party’s stunning loss of the Senate election in Massachusetts. Even so, by promoting the ideas of Paul Volcker  the esteemed former Federal Reserve chairman  the White House is finally elevating the discourse on how best to rein in risky behavior at banks and protect beleaguered taxpayers from future bailouts of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Cultural Riches Turn to Rubble in Haiti Quake
articles.snippet: In stealing symbols that gave Haitians hope and common purpose, the earthquake cast a cloud over their future.
articles.abstract: In stealing symbols that gave Haitians hope and common purpose, the earthquake cast a cloud over their future.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Long before its ground started heaving, Haiti was already a byword for a broken place. Its leaders were considered kleptocrats; its people were jaw-droppingly poor. But there was still a pride that burst forth from the people here, linked both to the country’s heroic history and to the vibrant culture that united them and enabled them to endure.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Seeks to Widen Field of Play in Fall Elections
articles.snippet: Analysts say more House and Senate seats will be up for grabs in November as Republicans lure new candidates into more races.
articles.abstract: Analysts say more House and Senate seats will be up for grabs in November as Republicans lure new candidates into more races.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republicans are luring new candidates into House and Senate races, and the number of seats up for grabs in November appears to be growing, setting up a midterm election likely to be harder fought than anyone anticipated before the party’s big victory in Massachusetts last week.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Corporate Antagonism Goes Public
articles.snippet: In a few recent business scuffles — Time Warner vs. News Corporation, Conan vs. NBC — the public was recruited to take sides rather than remain an observer.
articles.abstract: In a few recent business scuffles — Time Warner vs. News Corporation, Conan vs. NBC — the public was recruited to take sides rather than remain an observer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Time Warner Cable was tussling over fees with the News Corporation, it did something that would have been unthinkable in the backrooms where deals were once struck: it hired a political consultant to mount a public campaign against its own client.

articles.headline: A Playland for Apps in a Tablet World
articles.snippet: Apple’s anticipated tablet computer could lead developers to create games that two or more people can easily play at once on the same device, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Apple’s anticipated tablet computer could lead developers to create games that two or more people can easily play at once on the same device, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s move to open up the iPhone to outside programmers in 2008 started a software-writing frenzy. Giant companies and bedroom tinkerers alike rushed to get their applications into the App Store and onto the phone’s 3.5-inch touch screen.

articles.headline: In Drug War, Tribe Feels Invaded by Both Sides
articles.snippet: An Indian reservation is caught between the U.S. and Mexico as a major transit point for drugs as well as people.
articles.abstract: An Indian reservation is caught between the U.S. and Mexico as a major transit point for drugs as well as people.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELLS, Ariz.  An eerie hush settles in at sundown on the Tohono O’odham Nation, which straddles 75 miles of border with Mexico.

articles.headline: Conjuring Up the Latest Buzz, Without a Word
articles.snippet: Apple has said not a word about what it will introduce this week, and yet reporting about an expected tablet has gone on for months.
articles.abstract: Apple has said not a word about what it will introduce this week, and yet reporting about an expected tablet has gone on for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Wednesday, Steven P. Jobs will step to the stage at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco and unveil a shiny new machine that may or may not change the world.

articles.headline: Next News From Haiti: Pulling Out
articles.snippet: Coverage of the devastation has dominated the public’s attention, but financial concerns are leading TV networks to cut back their efforts.
articles.abstract: Coverage of the devastation has dominated the public’s attention, but financial concerns are leading TV networks to cut back their efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The CNN anchor Anderson Cooper knows the 24-hour news cycle as well as anyone, and last week, he lamented that the survivors of the Haiti earthquake would soon fall victim to that reality.

articles.headline: Volatility and Politics Are Feeding Fears of a Market Correction
articles.snippet: Investors say the discrepancy between gung-ho stock markets and a ho-hum economic recovery is a sign that an adjustment may be under way.
articles.abstract: Investors say the discrepancy between gung-ho stock markets and a ho-hum economic recovery is a sign that an adjustment may be under way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brace yourself for another wild ride on Wall Street.

articles.headline: On Street Tracing Haiti’s Pain, Survival Goes On
articles.snippet: A street in Port-au-Prince offers a snapshot of difficulties residents still face two weeks after the devastating quake.
articles.abstract: A street in Port-au-Prince offers a snapshot of difficulties residents still face two weeks after the devastating quake.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Avenue Poupelard in the center of this devastated city pulses with life and reeks of death almost two weeks after the earthquake.
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Obama to Offer Aid for Families in State of the Union Address
articles.snippet: In his speech on Wednesday, the president will focus on struggling families squeezed between sending their children to college and caring for elderly parents.
articles.abstract: In his speech on Wednesday, the president will focus on struggling families squeezed between sending their children to college and caring for elderly parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose in his State of the Union address a package of modest initiatives intended to help middle-class families, including tax credits for child care, caps on some student loan payments and a requirement that companies let workers save automatically for retirement, senior administration officials said Sunday.
